Posts.Content: biddy wrote: My mother-in-law (who lives with me) was diagnosed with Stage 4 IBC today.  I take her for a PET scan later this week, then she'll see the surgeon and a medical oncologist next Tuesday (and a radiation-oncologist Friday) to discuss options.  Her health is fragile in that she has minor dementia, gastrointestinal issues, and ambulates very slowly with a walker.  I'm praying that the doctors will make recommendations based on what's best for her and not what's best for them (prolonged treatment...$$$).  What's the oldest person on here with Stage VI IBC that has gone through aggressive treatment, and how did you do?  I would love to hear your stories.  Prayers and best wishes to you all. Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 11:53PM biddy wrote: Thanks all for your feedback.  Special K -- it's Invasive BC...not Inflammatory...  The preliminary pathology says "invasive ductal carcinoma with focal micropapillary features, grade 3...micropapillary variants of infiltrating mammary carcinoma are associated with higher stage and lymph node metastisis..."  The ER, PR, & HER wasn't available on the preliminary report, but will be ready when she sees both the surgeon (for an overview of all test results, including PET scan she had yesterday), and her first visit with oncologist to find out treatment options.  You would have to know my mother-in-law to fully understand this, but death just doesn't exist in her vocabulary -- not without a sense of shock that it actually happened.  As she receives news that a long-time friend or acquantance has died, she always reacts with shock.  So I feel certain she will take whatever steps the doctors outline if it will prolong her life.  I'm just concerned that she's not physically strong enough to handle it.  But after reading all of the posts on this wall, it sounds like they keep a close eye on things during chemo and radiation and stop treatment if it's causing more pain than gain.  I'll continue to post as we hopefully get further down the treatment trail.  Hugs to you all.
Posts.Title: Is 81 too old for aggressive treatment? biddy sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 10:37PM biddy wrote: Peggy -- I don't know about the hormone things yet.  Don't really even understand them yet.  BC is new to me, but I'm learning fast.   I guess they'll tell us about that next week.  All I know is that because it's Invasive Breast Cancer, and because that's one of the bad boys in terms of fast moving...hormone therapy isn't an option, at least not yet.  She has to start out with chemo and possibly a combination of chemo and radiation concurrently.  Thanks for the reminder about the confidentiality forms.  So far, I've been sure to get that covered, but she'll be seeing several new doctors in the upcoming weeks and I'll need to stay on my toes.  My husband has MS and I've been taking care of him for several years, so know the drill on that...however, I also know that you have to be vigilent... I'm sorry to hear your mother also has this nasty disease but glad she's been successful in keeping it at bay.  I wish her continued success in the fight for life.  What kind of BC does/did she have?
